huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This is a very productive unit with one of the largest deer herds in the state.  Muzzleloader hunters will find most success hunting on summer habitats at 7,500 feet and above.  In some years hunting on water sources can be productive but water is generally not limiting on the Manti portion of this unit.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Weather conditions in late September are generally pretty mild with warm days and cold nights.  There is rarely snow on the ground during this hunt and most deer are still found on high elevation summer ranges.  Roads are generally in good shape.  Be prepared for cold nights and occasional rainstorms which can make the roads muddy.  This can disrupt hunting and deer behavior as well as the ability to hunt on a water source.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 34.3~28000 Manti, 1000 San Rafael~25500 Manti, 1000 San Rafael~15–17~17.3~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
General Considerations: This is a very productive unit with one of the largest deer herds in the state.  Muzzleloader hunters will find most success hunting on summer habitats at 7,500 feet and above.  In some years hunting on water sources can be productive but water is generally not limiting on the Manti portion of this unit.  

Migration Patterns:
There is very little deer migration during the muzzleloader hunt.  Deer remain on summer ranges typically at 7,500 feet and above.  When migration begins (typically in mid October to mid-December) deer move down in elevation to the sagebrush benches east of SR-89 on the west and the sagebrush benches west of SR-6 and SR-10 on the east side of the mountain.  There is very little seasonal movement of deer on the San Rafael portion of the unit.


Mule Deer rut:
The mule deer rut usually runs from mid Nov.-mid Dec. so it does not affect this hunt.  


Recommended areas to hunt:

Upper Fish Creek and it's tributaries.  The tributaries include Gooseberry Creek, Silver Creek, C Canyon, and the Straight Fork.  This is a roadless area on the north end of the unit.  This area has had some prescribed fires recently that has improved deer habitat.  It can be accessed from North Skyline Drive on the west or from Scofield Reservoir on the east.  The bottom two miles of Upper Fish Creek is privately owned and in a CWMU
Bear Ridge and Fish Creek Ridge  These ridges have roads going down them.  They are northwest of Scofield Reservoir.   The bottom 2 miles of these ridges are privately owned.  This is excellent habitat in the Pondtown Creek drainage on the north end of the unit.  It is best accessed from North Skyline Drive.
Trough Spring Ridge  This is accessed off of SR-264 southwest of the town of Scofield.  It is just above the Skyline Coal Mine.  This is the ridge on the east side of Electric Lake.  There are some small pockets of private land that are posted well but the majority of the acreage is Forest Service.  Much of this ridge burned in the Seeley Wildfire in 2012 which has improved the deer habitat in this area.
Gentry Mountain.  This is accessed from SR-10 just north of the town of Huntington at Huntington Reservoir.  Part of this mountain is privately owned and part of it burned in the Seeley Wildfire in 2012
West of Skyline Drive All the small towns along the west face of the Central Mountains Manti Unit has a canyon road to connect to Skyline Drive.  Some roads are fairly rough going with the better access up from Fairview, Ephraim and Mayfiled.  Concentrate on side roads and trails from the main canyon roads to get to the more likely areas to find deer.  The higher elevations in aspen and sagebrush meadows with water in close proximity will hold some of the mature bucks.  Down low in the agricultural valleys many younger bucks will use the alfalfa fields in the evenings and early morning. Much of the adjacent property along the agriculture is either Forest Service or State lands and there will be a good  opportunities there.
East of Skyline Drive and South of Huntington Canyon There is a considerable amount of access along Skyline Drive, high elevation ridge tops, and lower canyons and valleys. There are also many areas where you can hike to get away from roads, much of it very steep, but where nice bucks hold up.  Some preliminary scouting with maps is a great way to familiarize yourself with the unit. One of the best options is Google Earth which you can use to really narrow down an area where you might want to start scouting.  Th

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: Voluntary: The DWR conducts random surveys for all general season hunts. You may be contacted via phone to participate in this survey.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of the deer habitat is on public lands.  The high elevation habitats on the Wasatch Plateau (Manti unit) are managed primarily by the Manti La Sal National Forest and are public lands.  Most of the low elevation habitat on the San Rafael portion of the unit is public land managed by the BLM.  Some notable exceptions include the area around Scofield Reservoir that has a high proportion of private lands managed under the CWMU program,  and the irrigated farmlands surrounding most of the rural communities along SR-10 in Emery County, and SR-89 in Sanpete County.  Prior permission must be secured before hunting on private lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Gordon Creek, Lower Fish Creek, Starvation, Dairy Fork, Lake Fork, Birdseye, Lasson Draw, White Hill, Black Hill, Bald Mountain, Sixmile, Nine Mile, Twelve Mile, Miller Manti Face, Willow Creek, Desert Lake, Huntington, Upper San Rafael, Lower San Rafael
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: All Campgrounds on the Manti part of this unit are managed by the US Forest Service. This unit is on the Manti La Sal National Forest. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites at http://www.fs.usda.gov/mantilasal. There are also numerous dispersed camping opportunities on the BLM lands on the San Rafael portion of the unit. There are very few developed campgrounds in these desert habitats. For information on BLM Campsites contact the Price BLM office at www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/price.html
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: The 1:100,000 scale maps that cover this unit include; Hanksville, Hite Crossing, San Rafael Desert, Huntington, Price, Nephi, Manti, Salina
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO: Most roads and ATV trails on the Manti part of the unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service at http://www.fs.usda.gov/mantilasal All roads and ATV trails on the San Rafael part of the unit are managed by the BLM and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Most major roads are maintained by Carbon and Emery Counties. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Price BLM office at www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/price.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are no Tribal Land issues on this unit. The vast majority of the archery deer summer habitat on the Manti portion of the unit is on public land. A few exceptions include the following areas; The northeast portion of the mountain near Scofield Reservoir has a high percentage of private land on good deer habitat. Most of these lands are managed under the CWMU program and can not provide hunter access as your permit will not be valid on those properties. Other private properties require prior written permission before hunting. Small pockets of private lands at high elevations can be found surrounding Electric Lake and on East Mountain. Archery hunters hunting around the irrigated fields along SR-10 in Emery County and SR-89 in Sanpete County will be hunting almost entirely on private land. Most of the desert portions of the San Rafael portion of the unit is on public land.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Carbon, Emery, Sanpete, Sevier and Utah counties—Boundary begins US-6 and US-89 in Spanish Fork Canyon; southeast on US-6 to I-70; east on I-70 to the Green River; south along this river to the Colorado River; south along this river (and the west shore of Lake Powell) to SR-95; north on SR-95 to SR-24 (hunters may harvest deer within 2 miles south of SR-24 between SR-95 and the Notom Road); west on SR-24 to Caineville and the Caineville Wash road; north on this road to the Cathedral Valley road; west on this road to Rock Springs Bench and the Last Chance Desert road; north on this road to the Blue Flats road; north and east on this road to the Willow Springs road; north on this road towards Windy Peak and the Windy Peak road; north on this road to I-70; west on I-70 to US-89; north on US-89 to US-6 in Spanish Fork Canyon. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Hanksville, Hite Crossing, Huntington, La Sal, Loa, Manti, Nephi, Price, Salina, San Rafael Desert. Boundary questions?  Call the Price office, 435-613-3700.
